messageBody:
Hi,

Are introductions required?
Rob Swan, Developmet/Project Manager, Casmir Ltd., UK

For software quality two of the most important things to test for
(if you can) are:
1. Connections are 'clean' when you put them back in the pool.
The next piece of code to use the connection should be able to
do so without fear of picking up a bad connection or one which
wasn't tidied up properly by the last user.
2. That when a connection is returned to the pool the code or module
which returned it doesn't use it any more.

It's great if you can test for this in the pools but doing so may be
as much a design issue as a testing one.

Good luck.
Rob.

From: Peter Cullinan [mailto:Peter.Cullinan@...]

Subject: [junit] Testing Connection Pools


Dear all

I want to know what is the most efficient way of testing the connection
pools. At the moment I am thinking of using Mike Clarkes JUnitPerf, is this
the correct road to go on. And if it is then, has anybody got any tips to
implement the test.

What are the most important things to test ?
1) The time to get a connection from the pool is one of the trivial things I
guess.
2) Load testing.

Any other good suggestions ?
How do I carry out the testing ?

Thanking you in anticipation of your response, kindest regards-

Peter Cullinan, junior java software tester
